abstract: A rebellion is brewing in the communications industry that is expected to pit wireless carriers against Silicon Valley powerhouses like Google.
snippet: A rebellion is brewing in the communications industry that is expected to pit wireless carriers against Silicon Valley powerhouses like Google.
lead_paragraph: First come the grumblings, then the torches and pitchforks.

headline.main: Cellphone Straitjacket Is Inspiring a Rebellion
headline.print_headline: Cellphone Straitjacket Is Inspiring A Rebellion

abstract: Mozilla has come to resemble a Silicon Valley start-up more than a scrappy collaborative underdog.
snippet: Mozilla has come to resemble a Silicon Valley start-up more than a scrappy collaborative underdog.
lead_paragraph: Only a couple of years ago, Firefox was the little browser that could — an open-source program created by thousands of contributors around the world without the benefit of a giant company like Microsoft to finance it.

headline.main: Will Success, or All That Money From Google, Spoil Firefox?
headline.print_headline: Will Success, or All That Money From Google, Spoil Firefox?

abstract: After five years of kneading Google engineers’ backs, Bonnie Brown retired and cashed in her stock options.
snippet: After five years of kneading Google engineers’ backs, Bonnie Brown retired and cashed in her stock options.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 11 — Bonnie Brown was fresh from a nasty divorce in 1999, living with her sister and uncertain of her future. On a lark, she answered an ad for an in-house masseuse at Google, then a Silicon Valley start-up with 40 employees. She was offered the part-time job, which started out at $450 a week but included a pile of Google stock options that she figured might never be worth a penny.

headline.main: Google Options Make Masseuse a Multimillionaire
headline.print_headline: Google Options Put Masseuse In Crowd of Multimillionaires

headline.main: For Masseuse, Google Options Made Millions

abstract: Google tries to lure developers for its new phone software with prize money. And why not? A similar strategy appears to be working for Facebook.
snippet: Google tries to lure developers for its new phone software with prize money. And why not? A similar strategy appears to be working for Facebook.
lead_paragraph: One of the big challenges for Google’s ambitious phone project is persuading software developers to write interesting applications. Already, developers of mobile phone programs complain about having to write for too many different software platforms, like Windows Mobile, Symbian, Palm, RIM, and soon, Apple’s iPhone. And while those software platforms are already powering millions of phones, there are no phones out there running Google’s “Android” system — and there won’t be any until the second half of next year.

headline.main: Seeding the Google Phone With Apps

abstract: Like that other search company, Yahoo is trying to build ties to researchers who can develop better ways to use huge clusters of computers.
snippet: Like that other search company, Yahoo is trying to build ties to researchers who can develop better ways to use huge clusters of computers.
lead_paragraph: There’s actually a lot of good stuff going on at Yahoo, but there is also a tendency for the company to come off like a Google wannabe. Take this release: Yahoo! Launches New Program to Advance Open-Source Software for Internet Computing.

headline.main: Is It Spelled Yahoogle or Yoogle?

abstract: Google gives a first look at what Google Phones based on the Android software will look like. Think iPhone.
snippet: Google gives a first look at what Google Phones based on the Android software will look like. Think iPhone.
lead_paragraph: O.K. There is no Google Phone. As we wrote a while back, Google is not building a phone. Instead, the company has teamed up with others in the wireless industry to create an open-source operating system, as well as other services, for mobile phones. Other companies, including Motorola, LG and Samsung, are expected to build phones based on this software.

headline.main: A First Look at the Google Phone
